  • Exports

Framebuffers and renderbuffers for rendering to textures.

Imports

enums, framebuffer_attachment, gl, pixelbuffer, pixeltypes, rect, target, window

Types

Renderbuffer[T] = ref object of FramebufferAttachment
  window: Window
  gl: OpenGl
  id: GlUint
  fSize: Vec2i
  fSamples: int
Renderbuffers are special buffer types similar to textures, but not suited for sampling. These are commonly used for depth and stencil buffers as they have lower overhead than using a full texture. Data cannot be uploaded to renderbuffers, as their only purpose is to function as depth and stencil attachments.   Source Edit 
RenderbufferPixelType = AnyPixelType
  Source Edit 
BaseFramebuffer = ref object of RootObj
  window: Window
  gl: OpenGl
  glfb: Framebuffer
  fSize: Vec2i
  fSamples: int
  pixelBuffer: PixelBuffer
Base type for framebuffers.   Source Edit 
DefaultFramebuffer {...}{.final.} = ref object of BaseFramebuffer
Object representation of the default framebuffer.   Source Edit 
SimpleFramebuffer {...}{.final.} = ref object of BaseFramebuffer
  fColor, fDepth, fStencil, fDepthStencil: FramebufferAttachment
Framebuffer with only one color attachment.   Source Edit 
MultiFramebuffer {...}{.final.} = ref object of BaseFramebuffer
  fColor: seq[FramebufferAttachment]
  fDepth, fStencil, fDepthStencil: FramebufferAttachment
Framebuffer with one or more color attachments.   Source Edit 
FramebufferTarget = object of Target
  framebuffer: BaseFramebuffer
  Source Edit 
BufferBit = enum
  bbColor, bbDepth, bbStencil
  Source Edit 
BlitFilter = range[fmNearest .. fmLinear]

proc blit(source, dest: BaseFramebuffer; sourceArea, destArea: Recti;
         buffers: set[BufferBit]; filter: BlitFilter) {...}{.
    raises: [Exception, ValueError], tags: [RootEffect].}
Blits an area from one framebuffer to another. sourceArea and destArea specify the area from which to copy, and the area to copy the pixels to. ## buffers specifies which buffers to copy, and filter specifies the filtering mode. Both framebuffers must have the same parent window, attempting to use framebuffers created with different windows is an error.   Source Edit 
proc download[T: ClientPixelType](framebuffer: BaseFramebuffer; area: Recti; callback: proc (
    data: ptr UncheckedArray[T]; len: Natural))

Asynchronously download pixels off the graphics card from the given ara, in the given format. This calls the callback procedure after the pixels are downloaded, which may take some amount of time to accomplish. This callback retrieves a pointer to the downloaded array of pixels with read-only access, along with the amount of pixels (not bytes!) stored in that array.

If you wish to preserve this data in a seq or some other container, use copyMem(data[0].addr, theSeq[0].addr, len * sizeof(T)). Passing the data array anywhere outside of this callback is undefined behavior (most likely resulting in a crash).

This procedure is asynchronous. Don't forget to update the window's async event loop using pollAsyncCallbacks, pollEvents, or waitEvents. Otherwise the results will never arrive.

  Source Edit 
proc download[T: ClientPixelType](framebuffer: BaseFramebuffer; area: Recti;
                                callback: proc (data: seq[T]))
Version of download that yields a seq. This seq contains an owned copy of the data stored in the framebuffer, so it's safe to assign it to somewhere else outside of the callback.   Source Edit 
proc downloadSync[T: ClientPixelType](framebuffer: BaseFramebuffer; area: Recti): seq[
    T]

Synchronously download pixels off the graphics card from the given area, in the given format.

This procedure is synchronous, so the results are available immediately. However, it forces a synchronization between the CPU and the GPU. This can negatively impact performance if it is called frequently. Prefer the asynchronous versions whenever possible.

  Source Edit

    raises: [Exception, ValueError, IOError], tags: [RootEffect].}
Creates a new simple framebuffer with color, depth, and stencil attachments. All attachments must have the same size and sample count, otherwise an assertion is triggered.   Source Edit

                   depthStencil: DepthStencilSource): SimpleFramebuffer {...}{.

proc newFramebuffer(window: Window; color: openArray[ColorSource];
                   depth: DepthSource; stencil: StencilSource): MultiFramebuffer {...}{.
    raises: [Exception, ValueError, IOError], tags: [RootEffect].}

Creates a new multi framebuffer with color, depth, and stencil attachments. All attachments must have the same size and sample count, otherwise an assertion is triggered.

Caution: When using multi framebuffers, you may find that source converters defined by Textures and Renderbuffers don't really work with the color openArray. In this case, you need to call these converters explicitly.

  Source Edit 
proc newFramebuffer(window: Window; color: openArray[ColorSource]; depth: DepthSource): MultiFramebuffer {...}{.
    raises: [Exception, ValueError, IOError], tags: [RootEffect].}
Creates a new multi framebuffer with color and depth attachments. All attachments must have the same size and sample count, otherwise an assertion is triggered.   Source Edit

                   stencil: StencilSource): MultiFramebuffer {...}{.
    raises: [Exception, ValueError, IOError], tags: [RootEffect].}

                   depthStencil: DepthStencilSource): MultiFramebuffer {...}{.
    raises: [Exception, ValueError, IOError], tags: [RootEffect].}

proc render(framebuffer: BaseFramebuffer): FramebufferTarget {...}{.raises: [], tags: [].}
Creates and returns a target for rendering onto the framebuffer. This proc is safe to use this in your render loop, as it does not have heavy performance implications. Also, the target returned from this proc does not have to be finish()``ed, unlike a window ``Frame.   Source Edit
